import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import missingno as msno
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
source.96f8d6ab:
null_count = df.isnull().sum()
# create figure
fig = plt.figure(figsize =(13,5))
ax = fig.add_axes([0,0,1,1])
# set Y axis label
ax.set_ylabel('count')
# set orientation for X axis labels
plt.xticks(rotation=30)
# draw bar chart
ax.bar(df.columns, null_count,color=['#F08080'])
fig.figure.suptitle(' Count of Null values in different features ',y=1.1, size = 20, color = theme[3], weight='bold');
plt.show()
source.6a6829b7:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,7))
ax = sns.countplot(x = df['ReleaseYear'],palette='flare')
plt.xlabel("Release Year", fontsize=13,weight = 'bold')
plt.ylabel("Count", fontsize=13,weight = 'bold')

#patches
for a in ax.patches:
    #value shows the count of each bar
    value = f'{a.get_height():.0f}'
    # x and y set the position of text over the bar
    x = a.get_x()+0.2
    y = a.get_height()+50 
    ax.text(x, y, value, ha='left', va='center', fontsize=10, 
            bbox=dict(facecolor='#D1F2EB', edgecolor='black', boxstyle='round', linewidth=0.5))
plt.title("Number of Games released each year",size=18,weight='bold',pad=20,color='#2C3E50')
plt.show();
source.f3bd972e:
#completion time is in string , we have to change it to int value
#we will take the average value :::: For example , if it is 1-2 hours --- it will be 1.5 hours.
arr = []
for i in df['CompletionTime']:
    if type(i)!= float and i!='200+':
        x= int(i.split('-')[0])
        y= int(i.split('-')[1])
        i = (x+y)/2
    elif i=='200+':
        i= 200
    else:
        i=i
    arr.append(i)
    
df['CompletionTimeNew']=arr
source.56b35d65:
plt.figure(figsize=(20,7))
ax1 = sns.countplot(x = df['CompletionTimeNew'],palette='husl')
plt.xlabel("Completion time of game (Hours)", fontsize=13,weight = 'bold')
plt.ylabel("Count", fontsize=13,weight = 'bold')

#patches
for a in ax1.patches:
    #value shows the count of each bar
    value = f'{a.get_height():.0f}'
    # x and y set the position of text over the bar
    x = a.get_x()+0.2
    y = a.get_height()+30 
    ax1.text(x, y, value, ha='left', va='center', fontsize=10, 
            bbox=dict(facecolor='#D1F2EB', edgecolor='black', boxstyle='round', linewidth=0.5))
plt.title("Number of games of different durations",size=18,weight='bold',pad=20,color='#2C3E50')
plt.show();

source.6fb35973:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,7))
ax2 = sns.countplot(y="Publisher", data=df, palette="flare",order=df.Publisher.value_counts().iloc[:9].index)
plt.ylabel("Publishers", fontsize=18,weight = 'bold')
plt.xlabel("Count", fontsize=15,weight = 'bold')
#patches
for a in ax2.patches:
    #value shows the count of each bar
    value = f'{a.get_width():.0f}'
    # x and y set the position of text over the bar
    x = a.get_x() + a.get_width() + 3.5
    y = a.get_y() + a.get_height() / 2
    ax2.text(x, y, value, ha='left', va='center', fontsize=11, 
            bbox=dict(facecolor='#D1F2EB', edgecolor='black', boxstyle='round', linewidth=0.5))
plt.title("Game count by Famous publishers",size=18,weight='bold',pad=20,color='#2C3E50')
plt.show();
source.324feb29:
plt.figure(figsize=(15,7))
ax3 = sns.countplot(y="Developer", data=df, palette="flare",order=df.Developer.value_counts().iloc[:9].index)
plt.ylabel("Developers", fontsize=18,weight = 'bold')
plt.xlabel("Count", fontsize=15,weight = 'bold')
#patches
for a in ax3.patches:
    #value shows the count of each bar
    value = f'{a.get_width():.0f}'
    # x and y set the position of text over the bar
    x = a.get_x() + a.get_width() + 1.1
    y = a.get_y() + a.get_height() / 2.0
    ax3.text(x, y, value, ha='left', va='center', fontsize=12, 
            bbox=dict(facecolor='#D1F2EB', edgecolor='black', boxstyle='round', linewidth=0.5))
plt.title("Game count by Famous Developers",size=18,weight='bold',pad=20,color='#2C3E50')
plt.show();
source.6aed748a:
col = "Genre"
grouped = df[col].value_counts().reset_index().iloc[:30]
grouped = grouped.rename(columns = {col : "count",'index':col})

## plot
trace = go.Pie(labels=grouped[col], values=grouped['count'], pull=[0.05, 0], marker=dict(colors=["#6ad49b", "#a678de"]))
layout = go.Layout(title="", height=600, legend=dict(x=1, y=1.1))
fig = go.Figure(data = [trace], layout = layout)
fig.show()

source.ff59f8b8:
#### Conclusion --- 2021 is the year when highest number of games are released.
##### Possible Reasons -- 
* Covid-19 --- People get more time to stay at home and play games.
* Advancement in gaming industry - Graphics , reality , game stories.
* Gamers can make their carrier in Gaming by participating in Internatinal tournaments and show their skills.
